title: Modenese Masters
text:
The Modenese Masters were three 18th-century <a href="chess%20master">chess master</a>s and writers from <a href="Modena">Modena</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>:
Together they were known as the "<a href="schools%20of%20chess%23Modenese%20school">Modenese school of chess</a>" . They recommended playing the <a href="Italian%20Game">Italian Game</a> <a href="chess%20opening">opening</a>. In contrast to <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois-Andr%C3%A9%20Danican%20Philidor">Philidor's</a> idea of <a href="pawn%20structure">pawn structure</a> and <a href="Glossary%20of%20chess%23Mobility">mobility</a>, the Modenese school emphasized rapid <a href="glossary%20of%20chess%23Develop">development</a> of the pieces for an attack on the opposing <a href="king%20%28chess%29">king</a>, aiming for <a href="checkmate">checkmate</a> or winning <a href="material%20%28chess%29">material</a> in the process .
